texts.shortText:
Pycnogonids are bizarre animals that are sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have 4 pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, since they are not closely-related to true spiders, we prefer to use the common name pycnogonids. The body consists of a head with a large tubular proboscis, a pair of grasping chelicerae, a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming and, in the males, to carry the eggs. Behind the head is a compact to elongate trunk consisting of usually four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes onto which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical, abdomen.

This species is readily identified in the field by the rounded knob in the centre of the back on each thoracic segment. The head also has a conical ocular tubercle with distinct black eyes and the proboscis is stout, cylindrical, tapering and extends directly forwards. Thoracic segments 3 and 4 are more or less fused with the junction, which is difficult to see. The legs are stout and also ornamented with small conical processes.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.
Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, and this species has only been recorded a few times so nothing is known about its specific biology.
Unknown, but almost all pycnogonids feed on cnidarians.

Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits. The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
The founded knobs on the back of each thoracic segment readily identify this species.

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 94, as Anatanais gracilis).

Bird, GJ (2008). Untying the Gordian Knot: on Tanais novaezealandiae Thomson (Crustacea, Tanaidacea, Tanaidae) from New Zealand, with descriptions of two new Zeuxoides species. Zootaxa, 1877(1), 1-36.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 84).
